attributes.comment:
While understanding the need to close funding gaps, I speak as someone who has
has bourne the significant costs associated with international adoptions. As you
know, the government has tried to lessen the burden on families such as mine by
providing a tax credit for adoption expenses on federal income taxes. While that
credit is certainly helpful, it is less than half what a typical international adoption
costs. To me, the government seems at cross-purposes if one branch takes
action to defray particiular costs, while another takes action to increase those
same costs.

What is it we are trying to encourage? I find it ironic that as I write, Congress is
considering raising the federal tax on tobacco. Beyond the fact that we cold raise
significant revenue with such an increase, there's a higher logic at work in that
situation because no doubt the government would like to discourage people from
using tobacco products. By the same token, I was under the impression that the
government would like to encourage people to adopt children in need, both
domestically and abroad. I think this is the logic of the aforementioned tax credit.
To now raise immigration fees that pertain to children adopted from abroad--and in
some cases, the proposed increases are very substantial--would be to counteract
what you are trying to encourage.

I know decisions like this are not easy. But I hope you would reconsider the
current proposal so that families who are already struggling to do something the
government is on record supporting, would not be further burdened by the very
same government.

Comment on FR Doc # E7-01631
attributes.title: Comment Submitted by Anthony F. LoPresti
